Statistic Report 1 About this work

Statistic Report 1 About this work Title : Exploring Data Analysis of cervical cancer risk factor from the database: UCI Machine Learning Repository. Author : A.Boniffay, Doctor of pharmacy and young machine learning student. Date : December 2024 Data references Fernandes,Kelwin, Cardoso,Jaime, and Fernandes,Jessica. (2017). Cervical Cancer (Risk Factors). UCI Machine Learning Repository. https://doi.org/10.24432/C5Z310.
introduction.html
2 Introduction 2.1 Contexte et objectifs 2.2 Description des données 2.3 Problématique

2 Introduction 2.1 Contexte et objectifs Le cancer du col de lutérus est lun des types de cancer les plus courants chez les femmes, en particulier dans les pays en développement. Le dépistage précoce et la compréhension des facteurs de risque sont essentiels pour améliorer les résultats en matière de santé publique. La base de données utilisée dans ce rapport, fournie par Fernandes et al.  (2017), contient des informations sur divers facteurs de risque potentiels pour le cancer du col de lutérus, notamment les antécédents médicaux, les comportements de santé et les résultats des tests cliniques. 2.2 Description des données La base de données contient 858 observations et 36 variables, dont 24 sont des variables qualitatives et 12 sont des variables quantitatives. Aucune colonne nest vide. Le nombre total dobservation manquante sur lentièreté du dataset est de 3622 observations sur xx observations soit xx %. 59 patients ont toutes leurs variables renseignées. la majorité des variables sont remplies à plus de 87%, 2 variables sont remplies à 86%, IUD (boolean qui indique la presence ou non dun dispositif intrauterin chez la patiente) et IUDYears (le nombre dannée que le dispositif à ete porté) 2 variables ont un taux de remplissage de 8%, TimeSinceFirstSTDs (qui correspond au temps depuis le premier diagnostique dIST) et TimeSinceLastSTDs (qui correspond au temps depuis le dernier diagnostique dIST) 2.3 Problématique Lobjectif de ce rapport est didentifier et danalyser les principaux facteurs de risque associés au cancer du col de lutérus à partir de la base de données. Nous explorerons comment ces facteurs sont reliés entre eux et si certains dentre eux peuvent prédire la survenue de résultats anormaux lors des tests de dépistage. ## Smokes HormonalContraceptives DxCancer DxCIN DxHPV ## "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" ## Dx Hinselmann Schiller Cytology Biopsy ## "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" ## STDs IUD STDsCondylomatosis STDsCervicalCondylomatosis STDsVaginalCondylomatosis ## "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" ## STDsVulvoPerinealCondylomatosis STDsSyphilis STDsPelvicInflammatoryDisease STDsGenitalHerpes STDsMolluscumContagiosum ## "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" ## STDsAIDS STDsHIV STDsHepatitisB STDsHPV NumberOfSexualPartners ## "logical" "logical" "logical" "logical" "numeric" ## FirstSexualIntercourse NumOfPregnancies STDsNumber STDsNumberOfDiagnosis TimeSinceFirstSTDs ## "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" ## TimeSinceLastSTDs Age SmokesYears SmokesPacksPerYear HormonalContraceptivesYears ## "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" "numeric" ## IUDYears ## "numeric"

3 Preprocessing 3.1 Global overview of the initial datset The dataset has 858 rows (observations) and 36 columns (variables), of which 24 are qualitative (categorical) and 12 are quantitative (numerical). The dataset doesnt contain any completely empty columns. There are 3,622 missing observations across the dataset, and only 59 complete rows with no missing data. The dataset consists of a total of 30,888 individual observations (858 rows x 36 columns), and the memory allocation for this dataset is 183.9 Kb. There are no obvious anomalies or outliers that might reflect data entry error or measurement bias. Behavioral and medical history variables (such as number of pregnancies, years of smoking or years on hormonal contraceptives) are consistent with what it would be observed in the real population. There is no medical justification for excluding observations, as none of the values are outside the ranges reasonably expected for the population studied. Data scientist  : However, it is essential to take a cautious approach to analysis, particularly when it comes to extreme values. These values, while legitimate from a medical point of view, can have a disproportionate impact on certain classic statistical measures, such as the mean. These extreme observations can bias the results and give a misleading picture of the overall trend. 5 Bivariate Analysis 5.1 Quantitative VS Outcome Outcome = DxCancer 5.1.1 Vizualisation 5.1.1.1 Boxplots by diagnosis 5.1.1.2 Density plots by diagnosis 5.1.2 Statistics This statistical section will allow us to observe whether there is a significant difference between patients diagnosed with cervical cancer and undiagnosed patients according to the different quantitative variables in the study. 6 Multivariate Analysis 6.1 Descriptive 6.2 Explicative

6 Multivariate Analysis To improve the results of the multivariate analysis, data has been normalised. scale() is used from the heatmaply library. description: scale() use Z-score. This method is robust to extreme values and retains information on the variance. 6.1 Descriptive 6.1.1 Standardisation & Dummification Figure 5 : Heatmap on initial data Figure 6 : Correlation matrix on standardised and dummy data On this figure, the values of the Pearson correlation coefficients (noted ) are indicated for each pair of variables. There are many variables that seem to have a linear relationship in the data frame Figure 6a : High correlation matrix (<0.8) Figure 6b : High correlation matrix (<0.8) The variable STDsCondylomatosis includes all the information from STDsVaginalCondylomatosis and STDsVulvoPerinealCondylomatosis. the latter two are therefore deleted in favour of STDsCondylomatosis. ## [1] 0 Figure 6c : High correlation matrix (<0.8) pelvic inflammatory disease is logically correlated at over 80% for all infectious variables. Does not provide additional information. STDsPelvicInflammatoryDisease is removed Figure 6d : High correlation matrix (<0.8) Viral_inf_HPV_HBV_GenHerp_Molluscum is created to condense and group informations about viral infection (STDsGenitalHerpes,STDsMolluscumContagiosum,STDsHepatitisB,STDsHPV,STDsHIV) Figure 7 : Correlation matrix with colinearity reduction Figure 8 : Heatmap on standardised data 6.1.2 PCA (Principal Composante Analysis) PCA: The aim is to understand the structure of the data and visualize relationships between variables. Figure 9 : ACP results 6.1.3 MCA (Multiple correspondence analysis) MCA: Similar to PCA, but used for qualitative data. It seeks to represent the relationships between the modalities of qualitative variables. Figure 10 : MCA results 6.1.4 FAMD (Factoriel Analysis Mixed Data) FAMD: Combines qualitative and quantitative variables, making it possible to explore mixed data without focusing on a target variable.
